speaker: PROSPERO
text_entry: ACT I

speaker: PROSPERO
text_entry: SCENE I. Athens. A hall in Timon's house.

speaker: PROSPERO
text_entry: Enter Poet, Painter, Jeweller, Merchant, and others, at several doors

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Good day, sir.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: I am glad you're well.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I have not seen you long: how goes the world?

speaker: Painter
text_entry: It wears, sir, as it grows.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Ay, that's well known:

speaker: Poet
text_entry: But what particular rarity? what strange,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Which manifold record not matches? See,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Magic of bounty! all these spirits thy power

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Hath conjured to attend. I know the merchant.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: I know them both; th' other's a jeweller.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: O, 'tis a worthy lord.

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: Nay, that's most fix'd.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: A most incomparable man, breathed, as it were,

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: To an untirable and continuate goodness:

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: He passes.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Jeweller: I have a jewel here--

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: O, pray, let's see't: for the Lord Timon, sir?

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Jeweller: If he will touch the estimate: but, for that--

speaker: Poet
text_entry: [Reciting to himself]  'When we for recompense have

speaker: Poet
text_entry: praised the vile,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: It stains the glory in that happy verse

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Which aptly sings the good.'

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: 'Tis a good form.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Looking at the jewel

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: And rich: here is a water, look ye.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: You are rapt, sir, in some work, some dedication

speaker: Painter
text_entry: To the great lord.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: A thing slipp'd idly from me.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Our poesy is as a gum, which oozes

speaker: Poet
text_entry: From whence 'tis nourish'd: the fire i' the flint

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Shows not till it be struck; our gentle flame

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Provokes itself and like the current flies

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Each bound it chafes. What have you there?

speaker: Painter
text_entry: A picture, sir. When comes your book forth?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Upon the heels of my presentment, sir.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Let's see your piece.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: 'Tis a good piece.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: So 'tis: this comes off well and excellent.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Indifferent.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Admirable: how this grace

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Speaks his own standing! what a mental power

speaker: Poet
text_entry: This eye shoots forth! how big imagination

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Moves in this lip! to the dumbness of the gesture

speaker: Poet
text_entry: One might interpret.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: It is a pretty mocking of the life.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Here is a touch; is't good?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I will say of it,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: It tutors nature: artificial strife

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Lives in these touches, livelier than life.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Enter certain Senators, and pass over

speaker: Painter
text_entry: How this lord is follow'd!

speaker: Poet
text_entry: The senators of Athens: happy man!

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Look, more!

speaker: Poet
text_entry: You see this confluence, this great flood

speaker: Poet
text_entry: of visitors.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I have, in this rough work, shaped out a man,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whom this beneath world doth embrace and hug

speaker: Poet
text_entry: With amplest entertainment: my free drift

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Halts not particularly, but moves itself

speaker: Poet
text_entry: In a wide sea of wax: no levell'd malice

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Infects one comma in the course I hold;

speaker: Poet
text_entry: But flies an eagle flight, bold and forth on,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Leaving no tract behind.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: How shall I understand you?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: I will unbolt to you.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: You see how all conditions, how all minds,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: As well of glib and slippery creatures as

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Of grave and austere quality, tender down

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Their services to Lord Timon: his large fortune

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Upon his good and gracious nature hanging

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Subdues and properties to his love and tendance

speaker: Poet
text_entry: All sorts of hearts; yea, from the glass-faced flatterer

speaker: Poet
text_entry: To Apemantus, that few things loves better

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Than to abhor himself: even he drops down

speaker: Poet
text_entry: The knee before him, and returns in peace

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Most rich in Timon's nod.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: I saw them speak together.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Sir, I have upon a high and pleasant hill

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Feign'd Fortune to be throned: the base o' the mount

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Is rank'd with all deserts, all kind of natures,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: That labour on the bosom of this sphere

speaker: Poet
text_entry: To propagate their states: amongst them all,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whose eyes are on this sovereign lady fix'd,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: One do I personate of Lord Timon's frame,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whom Fortune with her ivory hand wafts to her;

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Whose present grace to present slaves and servants

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Translates his rivals.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: 'Tis conceived to scope.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: This throne, this Fortune, and this hill, methinks,

speaker: Painter
text_entry: With one man beckon'd from the rest below,

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Bowing his head against the sleepy mount

speaker: Painter
text_entry: To climb his happiness, would be well express'd

speaker: Painter
text_entry: In our condition.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Nay, sir, but hear me on.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: All those which were his fellows but of late,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Some better than his value, on the moment

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Follow his strides, his lobbies fill with tendance,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Rain sacrificial whisperings in his ear,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Make sacred even his stirrup, and through him

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Drink the free air.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Ay, marry, what of these?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: When Fortune in her shift and change of mood

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Spurns down her late beloved, all his dependants

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Which labour'd after him to the mountain's top

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Even on their knees and hands, let him slip down,

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Not one accompanying his declining foot.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: 'Tis common:

speaker: Painter
text_entry: A thousand moral paintings I can show

speaker: Painter
text_entry: That shall demonstrate these quick blows of Fortune's

speaker: Painter
text_entry: More pregnantly than words. Yet you do well

speaker: Painter
text_entry: To show Lord Timon that mean eyes have seen

speaker: Painter
text_entry: The foot above the head.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Trumpets sound. Enter TIMON, addressing himself  courteously to every suitor; a Messenger from  VENTIDIUS talking with him; LUCILIUS and other servants following

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Imprison'd is he, say you?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Ay, my good lord: five talents is his debt,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: His means most short, his creditors most strait:

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your honourable letter he desires

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: To those have shut him up; which failing,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Periods his comfort.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Noble Ventidius! Well;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I am not of that feather to shake off

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: My friend when he must need me. I do know him

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A gentleman that well deserves a help:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Which he shall have: I'll pay the debt,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: and free him.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Your lordship ever binds him.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Commend me to him: I will send his ransom;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And being enfranchised, bid him come to me.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: 'Tis not enough to help the feeble up,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: But to support him after. Fare you well.

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All happiness to your honour!

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: Enter an old Athenian

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Lord Timon, hear me speak.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Freely, good father.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Thou hast a servant named Lucilius.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I have so: what of him?

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Most noble Timon, call the man before thee.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Attends he here, or no? Lucilius!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Here, at your lordship's service.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: This fellow here, Lord Timon, this thy creature,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: By night frequents my house. I am a man

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: That from my first have been inclined to thrift;

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: And my estate deserves an heir more raised

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Than one which holds a trencher.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Well; what further?

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: One only daughter have I, no kin else,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: On whom I may confer what I have got:

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: The maid is fair, o' the youngest for a bride,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: And I have bred her at my dearest cost

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: In qualities of the best. This man of thine

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Attempts her love: I prithee, noble lord,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Join with me to forbid him her resort;

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Myself have spoke in vain.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The man is honest.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Therefore he will be, Timon:

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: His honesty rewards him in itself;

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: It must not bear my daughter.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Does she love him?

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: She is young and apt:

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Our own precedent passions do instruct us

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: What levity's in youth.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: [To LUCILIUS]           Love you the maid?

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Ay, my good lord, and she accepts of it.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: If in her marriage my consent be missing,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: I call the gods to witness, I will choose

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Mine heir from forth the beggars of the world,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: And dispossess her all.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How shall she be endow'd,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: if she be mated with an equal husband?

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Three talents on the present; in future, all.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: This gentleman of mine hath served me long:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: To build his fortune I will strain a little,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: For 'tis a bond in men. Give him thy daughter:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What you bestow, in him I'll counterpoise,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And make him weigh with her.

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Most noble lord,

speaker: Old Athenian
text_entry: Pawn me to this your honour, she is his.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: My hand to thee; mine honour on my promise.

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Humbly I thank your lordship: never may

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: The state or fortune fall into my keeping,

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Which is not owed to you!

speaker: LUCILIUS
text_entry: Exeunt LUCILIUS and Old Athenian

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Vouchsafe my labour, and long live your lordship!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: I thank you; you shall hear from me anon:

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Go not away. What have you there, my friend?

speaker: Painter
text_entry: A piece of painting, which I do beseech

speaker: Painter
text_entry: Your lordship to accept.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Painting is welcome.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: The painting is almost the natural man;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: or since dishonour traffics with man's nature,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: He is but outside: these pencill'd figures are

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Even such as they give out. I like your work;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: And you shall find I like it: wait attendance

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Till you hear further from me.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: The gods preserve ye!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Well fare you, gentleman: give me your hand;

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: We must needs dine together. Sir, your jewel

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Hath suffer'd under praise.

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: What, my lord! dispraise?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: A more satiety of commendations.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: If I should pay you for't as 'tis extoll'd,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: It would unclew me quite.

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: My lord, 'tis rated

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: As those which sell would give: but you well know,

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: Things of like value differing in the owners

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: Are prized by their masters: believe't, dear lord,

speaker: Jeweller
text_entry: You mend the jewel by the wearing it.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Well mock'd.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: No, my good lord; he speaks the common tongue,

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Which all men speak with him.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Look, who comes here: will you be chid?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter APEMANTUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Jeweller: We'll bear, with your lordship.

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: He'll spare none.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Good morrow to thee, gentle Apemantus!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Till I be gentle, stay thou for thy good morrow;

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: When thou art Timon's dog, and these knaves honest.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Why dost thou call them knaves? thou know'st them not.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Are they not Athenians?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Then I repent not.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Jeweller: You know me, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou know'st I do: I call'd thee by thy name.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Thou art proud, Apemantus.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Of nothing so much as that I am not like Timon.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Whither art going?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: To knock out an honest Athenian's brains.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That's a deed thou'lt die for.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Right, if doing nothing be death by the law.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How likest thou this picture, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The best, for the innocence.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Wrought he not well that painted it?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: He wrought better that made the painter; and yet

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: he's but a filthy piece of work.

speaker: Painter
text_entry: You're a dog.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thy mother's of my generation: what's she, if I be a dog?

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Wilt dine with me, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No; I eat not lords.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: An thou shouldst, thou 'ldst anger ladies.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: O, they eat lords; so they come by great bellies.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: That's a lascivious apprehension.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So thou apprehendest it: take it for thy labour.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: How dost thou like this jewel, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Not so well as plain-dealing, which will not cost a

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: man a doit.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What dost thou think 'tis worth?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Not worth my thinking. How now, poet!

speaker: Poet
text_entry: How now, philosopher!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou liest.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Art not one?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Then I lie not.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Art not a poet?

speaker: Poet
text_entry: Yes.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Then thou liest: look in thy last work, where thou

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: hast feigned him a worthy fellow.

speaker: Poet
text_entry: That's not feigned; he is so.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Yes, he is worthy of thee, and to pay thee for thy

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: labour: he that loves to be flattered is worthy o'

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: the flatterer. Heavens, that I were a lord!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What wouldst do then, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: E'en as Apemantus does now; hate a lord with my heart.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What, thyself?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ay.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Wherefore?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That I had no angry wit to be a lord.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Art not thou a merchant?

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: Ay, Apemantus.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Traffic confound thee, if the gods will not!

speaker: Merchant
text_entry: If traffic do it, the gods do it.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Traffic's thy god; and thy god confound thee!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Trumpet sounds. Enter a Messenger

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: What trumpet's that?

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: 'Tis Alcibiades, and some twenty horse,

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: All of companionship.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Pray, entertain them; give them guide to us.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt some Attendants

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: You must needs dine with me: go not you hence

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Till I have thank'd you: when dinner's done,

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Show me this piece. I am joyful of your sights.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter ALCIBIADES, with the rest

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Most welcome, sir!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: So, so, there!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Aches contract and starve your supple joints!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: That there should be small love 'mongst these

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: sweet knaves,

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: And all this courtesy! The strain of man's bred out

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Into baboon and monkey.

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Sir, you have saved my longing, and I feed

speaker: ALCIBIADES
text_entry: Most hungerly on your sight.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Right welcome, sir!

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Ere we depart, we'll share a bounteous time

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: In different pleasures. Pray you, let us in.

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Exeunt all except APEMANTUS

speaker: TIMON
text_entry: Enter two Lords

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: What time o' day is't, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Time to be honest.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That time serves still.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: The more accursed thou, that still omitt'st it.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Thou art going to Lord Timon's feast?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Ay, to see meat fill knaves and wine heat fools.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Fare thee well, fare thee well.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Thou art a fool to bid me farewell twice.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Why, Apemantus?

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Shouldst have kept one to thyself, for I mean to

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: give thee none.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Hang thyself!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: No, I will do nothing at thy bidding: make thy

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: requests to thy friend.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Away, unpeaceable dog, or I'll spurn thee hence!

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: I will fly, like a dog, the heels o' the ass.

speaker: APEMANTUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: He's opposite to humanity. Come, shall we in,

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: And taste Lord Timon's bounty? he outgoes

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The very heart of kindness.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: He pours it out; Plutus, the god of gold,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Is but his steward: no meed, but he repays

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Sevenfold above itself; no gift to him,

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: But breeds the giver a return exceeding

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: All use of quittance.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: The noblest mind he carries

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: That ever govern'd man.

speaker: Second Lord
text_entry: Long may he live in fortunes! Shall we in?

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: I'll keep you company.

speaker: First Lord
text_entry: Exeunt
